1. A 5-year-old boy presents with episodes of exercise intolerance and muscle weakness, especially after prolonged activity. His parents report persistent hepatomegaly noted since infancy and occasional hypoglycemic episodes during fasting periods. On examination, he exhibits mild growth retardation and glycogen accumulation is suspected due to the distended liver palpable 4 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver transaminases and mild hyperlipidemia, while a muscle biopsy shows vacuolar myopathy with glycogen accumulation. Cardiac evaluation indicates mild ventricular hypertrophy, though the patient is currently asymptomatic from a cardiac standpoint. Family history reveals consanguinity but no known enzyme deficiencies. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the GBE1 gene, consistent with Glycogen Storage Disease type IV (Andersen disease). The patient is started on a tailored nutrition plan to avoid fasting and monitored closely for progressive liver dysfunction and neuromuscular symptoms.
